Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Actions have consequences; one must bear the result of their deeds.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You must face the outcome of your actions.
Usage Contexts: Daily speech, moral advice, family discussions
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in Wasa traditional fishing communities—‘kɔtɔ’ (crab) symbolizes responsibility.
First Example Sentence: Wɔka kɔtɔ no tua ne bo sɛ ɔyɛ bɔne a, ɛsɛ sɛ ɔtua ka no.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔkae no sɛ, ‘kɔtɔ no tua ne bo,’ na ɔsii gyinaeɛ no.
Third Example Sentence: Nananom ka sɛ, kɔtɔ no tua ne bo, enti yɛn nyinaa nsusuw yɛn dwuma ho.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A child’s behavior shows their upbringing or character.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A child's conduct reveals their moral training.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in Wasa family proverbs—emphasizes social responsibility of parents.
First Example Sentence: Abofra boɔ mu yɛ duru, enti fa no kɔhyɛ ɔpanyin nkyɛn.
Second Example Sentence: Wɔka sɛ abofra boɔ mu yɛ duru na ɛma ɔpanyin nni asomdwoeɛ.
Third Example Sentence: Ɛyɛ nokware sɛ abofra boɔ mu yɛ duru, ɛfiri sɛ nea ɔyɛ no, na ɛkyerɛ ne su.

Idiom (Wasa): Nanka bɔne wɔ ne nan so
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Clause with nominal subject and locative prepositional phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person known for evil is likely to repeat it.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A bad person will always show their nature.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in rural Wasa wisdom—‘nanka’ (crocodile) represents deceit and persistence.
First Example Sentence: Ɛka sɛ nanka bɔne wɔ ne nan so, enti hwɛ no yie.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔpanyin no kae sɛ nanka bɔne wɔ ne nan so berɛ a ɔrekyerɛ abofra no.
Third Example Sentence: Wɔka no wɔ kurom ha sɛ nanka bɔne wɔ ne nan so na ɛyɛ nokware.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: You must take initiative to learn or see progress.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: If you don’t try, you won’t discover anything new.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: From Wasa wisdom comparing human ambition to a bird’s curiosity.
First Example Sentence: Anomaa antu a, ɔbɛhu adeɛ, enti yɛn nyinaa nsa bɛka ho.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔka sɛ anomaa antu a, ɔbɛhu adeɛ na ɔhyɛɛ wɔn nkuran.
Third Example Sentence: Ɛyɛ asɛm a ɛkyerɛ sɛ anomaa antu a, ɔbɛhu adeɛ.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: No one truly knows what will happen in the future.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: The future is uncertain for everyone.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Ancient Wasa saying about destiny and humility before time.
First Example Sentence: Ɔkaa no sɛ obi nnim nea ɛrekɔ so, enti yɛn nyinaa bɔ mpaeɛ.
Second Example Sentence: Wɔte sɛ obi nnim nea ɛrekɔ so, na ɛyɛ nokware paa.
Third Example Sentence: Ɛda a ɔkae no sɛ obi nnim nea ɛrekɔ so, na ɛyɛ sɛ ɔhuu anidasoɔ.

Idiom (Wasa): Wohu abɛ a, ka sɛ ɛyɛ fɛ
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Praise what is beautiful when you see it.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from Wasa etiquette emphasizing communal appreciation.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Wasa): /wɔ.hʊ a.bɛ a ka sɛ ɛ.jɛ fɛ/
First Example Sentence: Wohu abɛ a, ka sɛ ɛyɛ fɛ, efisɛ nokware yɛ ahoɔfɛ.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔkae sɛ, 'wohu abɛ a, ka sɛ ɛyɛ fɛ' sɛnea ɛbɛma obi anigye.
Third Example Sentence: Sɛ wohu abɛ a, ka sɛ ɛyɛ fɛ, na ɛbɔ abusua mu dɔ.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: True character is revealed under difficult conditions.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People show their real selves in tough times.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from Wasa coastal life—crabs (‘kɔtɔ’) emerge when waters stir.
First Example Sentence: Ɛwɔ nsuo mu na ɛhunu kɔtɔ, enti ɛsɛ sɛ yɛyɛ nokware bere nyinaa.
Second Example Sentence: Wɔka sɛ nsuo mu na ɛhunu kɔtɔ na ɛma obi hu nea ɔyɛ nokware.
Third Example Sentence: Nsuo mu na ɛhunu kɔtɔ, sɛnea ɛte no wɔ abrabɔ mu.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: If you desire something valuable, accept its difficulties too.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You must accept the challenges that come with what you want.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: From rural Wasa life—chickens (‘akokɔ’) symbolize both sustenance and responsibility.
First Example Sentence: Ɔkae sɛ wopɛ akokɔ, gye ne mpɔnpɔ berɛ a ɔrekyerɛ abofra no.
Second Example Sentence: Wɔka sɛ wopɛ akokɔ, gye ne mpɔnpɔ, na ɛkyerɛ suban pa.
Third Example Sentence: Sɛ wopɛ akokɔ, gye ne mpɔnpɔ na ɛbɛma w’ani agye nsɛm no.

Idiom (Wasa): Ɔwɔ dua so a, ɔmfa ne nan ntɔ fam
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: When you are elevated, remain humble.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Stay humble even when you’re in a high position.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from ancient Wasa leadership proverbs emphasizing humility.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Wasa): /ɔ.wɔ dʊ.a sɔ a ɔ.mfa nɪ naŋ n.tɔ fam/
First Example Sentence: Ɔka sɛ ɔwɔ dua so a, ɔmfa ne nan ntɔ fam sɛnea ɔde n’ani si fam.
Second Example Sentence: Ɛyɛ sɛnea wopɛ sɛ ɔde ne ho si fam, ɔwɔ dua so a ɔmfa ne nan ntɔ fam.
Third Example Sentence: Ɔkyerɛ sɛ ɔwɔ dua so a, ɔmfa ne nan ntɔ fam, efisɛ anigye fi ahobrɛase mu.

Idiom (Wasa): Aboa biara pɛ ne kwaeɛ mu
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Independent clause with possessive noun phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Everyone prefers their comfort zone or place of origin.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Everyone loves their own home or environment.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Old Wasa rural saying—observes animals’ natural attachment to their habitat.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Wasa): /a.bʊ.a bɪ.a ra pɛ nɪ kwa.eɛ mʊ/
First Example Sentence: Aboa biara pɛ ne kwaeɛ mu, enti fa w’ade bɔ mu dɔ.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔka sɛ aboa biara pɛ ne kwaeɛ mu na ɛyɛ anigye wɔ nsɛm mu.
Third Example Sentence: Wɔte sɛ aboa biara pɛ ne kwaeɛ mu, ɛno nti obiara dɔ ne fie.
